description: Array of polygonal numbers T(n,k) = ((n-2)*k^2 - (n-4)*k)/2, n >= 2, k >= 1, read by antidiagonals.
comments: T(2n+4,n) = n^3. - Stuart M. Ellerstein (ellerstein(AT)aol.com), Aug 28 2000The sum of the antidiagonals = A000127(n+1) - 1. - _Raphie Frank_, Oct 05 2012
references: A. H. Beiler, Recreations in the Theory of Numbers. New York: Dover, p. 189, 1966.
J. H. Conway and R. K. Guy, The Book of Numbers, Springer-Verlag (Copernicus), p. 38, 1996.
links: T. D. Noe, Rows n = 2..100, flattened
formula: T(n, k) = T(n-1, k) + k*(k-1)/2 [with T(2, k)=k] = T(n, k-1) + 1 + (n-2)*(k-1) [with T(n, 0)=0] = k + (n-2)k(k-1)/2 = k + A063212(n-2, k-1). - _Henry Bottomley_, Jul 11 2001G.f. for row n: x*(1+(n-3)*x)/(1-x)^3, n>=2. - _Paul Barry_, Feb 21 2003From _Wolfdieter Lang_, Nov 05 2014: (Start)The triangle is a(n, m) = T(n-m+1, m) = (1/2)*m*(n*(m-1) + 3 - m^2) for n >= 2, m = 1, 2, ..., n-1 and zero elsewhere.O.g.f. for column m (without leading zeros):(x*binomial(m,2) + (1+2*m-m^2)*(m/2)*(1-x))/(x^(m-1)*(1-x)^2). (End)
